**Solution:**

::: {#loading-data-and-basic-processing .section .level3}
### 1. Loading data and basic processing 

::: {#a. .section .level4}
#### a.

Loading covid data, setting date variable's class.

``` r
covid_df = read.csv("C:/R/Datasets/owid-covid-data.csv")
covid_df$date = as.Date(covid_df$date)
print(paste0("The class of covid_df$date is: ",class(covid_df$date)))
```

    ## [1] "The class of covid_df$date is: Date"

As we can see the class of date is Date.
:::

::: {#b. .section .level4}
#### b.

Top five dates for every variable, decreasing order

``` r
covid_high_income = as.data.frame(subset(covid_df, location == 'High income'))

head(covid_high_income[order(covid_high_income$new_cases, decreasing = TRUE), ]
     %>% select(date, new_cases) %>% top_n(5, new_cases))
```

::: {pagedtable="false"}
:::

``` r
head(covid_high_income[order(covid_high_income$new_deaths, decreasing = TRUE), ]
     %>% select(date, new_deaths) %>% top_n(5, new_deaths))
```

::: {pagedtable="false"}
:::

``` r
head(covid_high_income[order(covid_high_income$new_vaccinations, decreasing = TRUE), ]
     %>% select(date, new_vaccinations) %>% top_n(5, new_vaccinations))
```

::: {pagedtable="false"}
:::

AS we can see, at 2022 the largest covid wave took place. One can say
that the vaccinations appearance in our lives decreased the deaths,
since that new deaths are the highest a year before the highest new
cases and between the highest new vaccinations (that's when the
vaccinations started to affect).
:::
:::

::: {#comparing-low-vs.-high-income-countries .section .level3}
### 2. Comparing low vs.Â high income countries 

::: {#a.-1 .section .level4}
#### a.

Generating a function that plots the value of given variable as a
function of the date for both High income & Low income countries

``` r
plot_by_income = function(covid_df,column)
{
  covid_by_income = subset(covid_df, location %in% c('High income', 'Low income'))
    ggplot(covid_by_income,
      aes_string(x="date", y=column ,color="location")) + 
      geom_line() +
      theme_bw() +
      labs(x="Date", y = column, title=("High & Low Income Plot")) +
      theme(legend.position = 'bottom')
}
```

Using ggplot and aes_string since our input would be the variables name
in class character.
:::

::: {#b.-1 .section .level4}
#### b.

Making plots using our function, comparing log smoothed plots to
regular.

``` r
covid_df$log_new_cases_smoothed_per_million = log(covid_df$new_cases_smoothed_per_million)

pl1 = plot_by_income(covid_df, "new_cases_per_million")
pl2 = plot_by_income(covid_df, "log_new_cases_smoothed_per_million") # smoothed
ggarrange(pl1, pl2 , ncol = 2, nrow = 1)
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
covid_df$log_new_deaths_smoothed = log(covid_df$new_deaths_smoothed)

pl3 = plot_by_income(covid_df, "new_deaths")
pl4 = plot_by_income(covid_df, "log_new_deaths_smoothed") # smoothed
ggarrange(pl3, pl4 , ncol = 2, nrow = 1)
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
covid_df$log_new_vaccinations_smoothed_per_million = 
  log(covid_df$new_vaccinations_smoothed_per_million)

pl5 = plot_by_income(covid_df, "new_vaccinations")
pl6 = plot_by_income(covid_df, "new_vaccinations_smoothed_per_million") # smoothed
ggarrange(pl5, pl6 , ncol = 2, nrow = 1)
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

The plot which is easier to interpret is the log smoothed one because
when we smooth the column values it's easier to observe the changes in
the low income countries (on the 'regular' plot we cannot interpret the
low income graph at all as it seems monotone).
:::
:::

::: {#storing-and-analyzing-current-cumulative-value .section .level3}
### 3. Storing and analyzing current (cumulative) value 

::: {#a.-2 .section .level4}
#### a.

Generating df of current values by country

``` r
vars = c('location', 'continent', 'total_cases_per_million','total_deaths_per_million', 
'total_vaccinations_per_hundred', 'people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred',
'total_boosters_per_hundred', 'excess_mortality_cumulative_per_million','date')

wanted_cur = subset(covid_df, select = vars) %>%  group_by(location)

filled_cur = fill(wanted_cur, names(wanted_cur), .direction = 'updown') # fill all na's

current = subset(filled_cur, date == max(wanted_cur$date))
current$date = NULL
```

We filled the values to be the last non Na value by date to be the most
up dated value and with group_by we ran over the location and generated
a data frame of the wanted variables by location.
:::

::: {#b.-2 .section .level4}
#### b.

Empirical distribution

``` r
hist(current$total_deaths_per_million, breaks= 30, col="skyblue3",
     main = "Histogram of total deaths per million", xlab= "total deaths per million")
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
print(paste0("The distibution skewness: ", skewness(current$total_deaths_per_million, na.rm=T)))
```

    ## [1] "The distibution skewness: 1.30647361588152"

``` r
print(paste0("The distibution kurtosis: ", kurtosis(current$total_deaths_per_million, na.rm=T)))
```

    ## [1] "The distibution kurtosis: 1.6238780513828"

This empirical distribution doesn't look like Normal since it only has a
right tail. A positive skewness indicates that the tail is on the right.
A kurtosis that is less than 3 means the dataset has lighter tails than
a normal distribution (less in the tails).
:::

::: {#c. .section .level4}
#### c.

Scatter of total deaths & total cases with linear regression

``` r
total_cases_per_million = current$total_cases_per_million
total_deaths_per_million = current$total_deaths_per_million

plot(x=total_cases_per_million, y=total_deaths_per_million, 
     main= 'Total Deaths Per Million  vs. Total Cases Per Million', 
     xlab= 'Total Cases Per Million', ylab = 'Total Deaths Per Million',
     col= 'skyblue3', pch=18)

reg = lm(total_deaths_per_million ~ total_cases_per_million,)
abline(reg, col='red', lwd=3)
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
print(paste0("The slope: ", summary(reg)$coefficients[2,1]))
```

    ## [1] "The slope: 0.0040800120531996"

Our slope is 0.004, which is positive and it means total cases per
million and total deaths per million are positively (weak) correlated.
:::
:::

::: {#vaccinations-in-different-continents .section .level3}
### 4. Vaccinations in different continents 

::: {#a.-3 .section .level4}
#### a.

Boxplot of vaccinations per hundered for every continent

``` r
continents = c('Africa','Asia', 'Europe','South America', 'North America', 'Oceania')
vaccinations_by_location = subset(current, select = c('continent', 'total_vaccinations_per_hundred'), continent %in% continents)

boxplot(total_vaccinations_per_hundred ~ continent, data = vaccinations_by_location,
        xlab = "Continent",
        ylab = "Total Vaccinations Per Hundred", 
        main = "Vaccinations Per Hundred By Location",
        col = c("green","yellow","purple", "red","skyblue", "darkblue"),
        names= c('Africa', 'Asia', 'Europe', 'N-America', 'Oceania', 'S-America'))
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
vaccinations_africa = subset(vaccinations_by_location, continent=='Africa')
vaccinations_europe = subset(vaccinations_by_location, continent=='Europe')

max_africa = max(vaccinations_africa$total_vaccinations_per_hundred, na.rm =T)
max_europe = max(vaccinations_europe$total_vaccinations_per_hundred, na.rm =T)

print(paste0("outlier 1: Seychelles, total vaccinations per hundred: ",max_africa))
```

    ## [1] "outlier 1: Seychelles, total vaccinations per hundred: 202.05"

``` r
print(paste0("outlier 2: Gibraltar,  total vaccinations per hundred: ",max_europe))
```

    ## [1] "outlier 2: Gibraltar,  total vaccinations per hundred: 354.93"

Africa has the most outliers, it is not surprising since most of low
income countries come from Africa. The mean of Africa is significantly
different from other continents, without the outliers that drag it
upwards it would have been even lower. All other means are more or less
close becase their error bars are more or less close.
:::

::: {#b.-3 .section .level4}
#### b.

Create & plot the booster ratio as a function of time for the six
continents

``` r
booster_by_date =  covid_df %>% group_by(date, continent) %>% summarise(total_boosters = sum(total_boosters, na.rm = T) ,total_vaccinated = sum(people_fully_vaccinated, na.rm = T), booster_ratio =ifelse(total_vaccinated > 0,
total_boosters/total_vaccinated, NA)) %>% filter(continent %in% continents, date >= "2021-01-01")

ggplot(booster_by_date,
      aes_string(x="date", y='booster_ratio',color="continent")) + 
      theme_bw() +
      geom_smooth() + # easier to interrupt using smooth 
      labs(x="Date", y = 'Booster Ratio', title=("Booster Ratio By Date")) 
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

firstly, we smoothed the lines in order to observe the graph trends
better. As we can see South America were the first to have a high
percentage of booster, than regressed and afterwards continued at a
similar rate as the other continents. Asia, Oceania and North America
received the booster early but it took time for the ratio to increase.
The rate of increase in booster ratio was the slowest in Africa &
fastest in Europe.
:::
:::

::: {#displaying-monthly-data .section .level3}
### 5. Displaying monthly data 

::: {#a.-4 .section .level4}
#### a.

plot the distribution of total number of `new_cases_per_million` for
each country by month (in chronological order) then, doing the same for
the total number of `new_deaths` and `new_vaccinations` for each month

``` r
month_df = subset(covid_df, date <= "2022-03-31" ) %>% group_by(date= format(as.Date(date),"%y-%m"), location) %>% summarise(
  new_cases_per_million = sum(new_cases_per_million), new_deaths = sum(new_deaths), new_vaccinations = sum(new_vaccinations))

boxplot(new_cases_per_million ~ date ,
data= month_df,
main="Months distribution of New Cases Per Million in chronical order",
ylim =c(0,100000), # y limit for better analysis of the plot
xlab = 'Date',
ylab = 'New Cases Per Million',
col = "green")
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

There's a large scattering and most days are not significantly
different. The distribution has a left tail and there's an increase
until 22-01 and a decrease afterwards (the effect of vaccines)
:::

::: {#b.-4 .section .level4}
#### b.

Doing the same as (a.) for the total number of `new_deaths` and
`new_vaccinations` for each month (chronological) we limit the y scale
in order to be able to read th plots and analyse the graph.

``` r
boxplot(new_deaths ~ date ,
data= month_df,
main="Months distribution of New Deaths in chronical order",
ylim = c(0,10000), # y limit for better analysis of the plot
xlab = 'Date',
ylab = 'New Deaths',
col = "red")
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
boxplot(new_vaccinations ~ date ,
data= month_df,
main="Months distribution of New Vaccinations in chronical order",
ylim = c(0,60000000), # y limit for better analysis of the plot,
xlab = 'Date',
ylab = 'New Vaccinations',
col = "skyblue3")
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

In both boxplots we can't tell an appear of a specific tendency, but we
can say that new deaths has more outliers and there's a left tail, the
mean is more or less similar after 21-01 (we can tell vaccines affected
the new deaths) and the variance if new vaccinations is very large in
21-09 and afterwards (more locations got a vaccine). Because the error
bars are not at a same rate we can say that comparison on the base of a

::: {#cross-correlations-and-delay-from-diagnosis-to-death .section .level3}
### 7. Cross correlations and delay from diagnosis to death 

::: {#a.-5 .section .level4}
#### a.

Function that generates cross cor vector for 2 column vector from a
given data frame.

``` r
cross_cor = function(df, country_name, col_1, col_2){
  
  new_df = subset(covid_df, location == country_name, select = c(col_1, col_2))
  
  cross_cor_vec = c()
  vec1 = new_df[,col_1]
  vec2 = new_df[,col_2]
  n = length(vec1)

  counter = 1
  
    for(t in -60:60){
    
    if(t <= 0){
      cross_cor_vec[counter] = cor(vec1[(1-t):n], vec2[1:(n+t)], use="pairwise.complete.obs") }

    else{
      cross_cor_vec[counter] = cor(vec1[1:(n-t)], vec2[(t+1):n],use="pairwise.complete.obs") }
    
      counter = counter + 1         
    }
  
  replace_na(cross_cor_vec, 0) # in case of an unwanted NA
  return(cross_cor_vec)  
}
```
:::

::: {#b.-5 .section .level4}
#### b.

Cross correlation between the `new_cases_smoothed` &
`new_deaths_smoothed` for `World`, plot as a function of `delta_t` above

``` r
cross_World = cross_cor(covid_df,'World','new_cases_smoothed','new_deaths_smoothed')

ggplot(df = data.frame(cross_World, -60:60)) +
  aes(x =-60:60, y = cross_World)+
  theme_bw() +
  geom_point(color = 'skyblue3')+
  labs(x='Delta-t', y = 'Cross-Cor', title=("World Cross-Cor of New Cases & New Deaths"))
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
print(paste0("Time delay that maximize cross-cor: ", (which.max(cross_World) - 61))) # length(-60:60)/2 = 121/2, rounding upwards to 61 
```

    ## [1] "Time delay that maximize cross-cor: 10"

As we can see the Time delay that maximize cross-cor is 10 which means
the typical time delay between diagnosis of Covid-19 and death from
Covid-19 for cases not surviving the disease is 10.
:::
:::

::: {#death-risk-after-covid-19-infection .section .level3}
### 9. Death risk after Covid-19 infection 

::: {#a.-6 .section .level4}
#### a.

Creating and plotting death rate as a function of time for all
continents, world

``` r
covid_df$death_rate = ifelse(covid_df$total_cases > 0, covid_df$total_deaths/covid_df$total_cases, NA)

covid_by_continent_date =  na.omit(group_by(covid_df, date, continent) %>% summarise(sum_total_cases = sum(total_cases, na.rm = T), sum_total_deaths = sum(total_deaths, na.rm = T), death_rate =ifelse(sum_total_cases > 0, sum_total_deaths/sum_total_cases, NA)) %>% filter(date >= as.Date('2021-01-01')))
covid_by_continent_date$continent[covid_by_continent_date$continent==''] = 'World'

ggplot(covid_by_continent_date,
      aes_string(x="date", y='death_rate',color="continent")) + 
      geom_line() +
      theme_bw() +
      labs(x="Date", y = 'death_rate', title=("Death Rate By Date"))
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}
:::

::: {#b.-6 .section .level4}
#### b.

A similar plot for all continents and the world, but for
`total_vaccinations_per_hundred`.

``` r
covid_by_date_location = na.omit(subset(covid_df, select = c(date, location, total_vaccinations_per_hundred), date >= as.Date('2021-01-01'))) %>% filter(location %in% c(continents, 'World'))

ggplot(covid_by_date_location,
      aes_string(x="date", y='total_vaccinations_per_hundred',color="location")) + 
      geom_line() + 
      theme_bw() +
      labs(x="Date", y = 'total_vaccinations_per_hundred', title=("Total Vaccinations By Date"))
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

We can see correlation between decrease in death rate and vaccinations
appearance. the death rate dropped drastically and remain low as the
vaccinations took place.
:::
:::

::: {#excess-mortality .section .level3}
### 9. Excess Mortality 

::: {#a.-7 .section .level4}
#### a.

Visualizing the excess mortality outlier countries and marking them on
the graph

``` r
low_line = geom_abline(intercept = -2000, slope = 1, col = 'skyblue3')
up_line = geom_abline(intercept = 2000, slope = 1, col = 'red')
middle_line = geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1)
beyond_rate = abs(current$excess_mortality_cumulative_per_million-total_deaths_per_million)>=2000
ggplot(current)+
  aes(x=total_deaths_per_million, y=excess_mortality_cumulative_per_million) +
  theme_bw() +
  geom_point(aes(color = beyond_rate)) +
  middle_line +
  up_line + 
  low_line +
  geom_text(aes(label=ifelse(beyond_rate, location, "")), size = 2) +
  labs(x="Total Deaths", y = 'Excess Mortality', title=("Total Deaths & Excess Mortality per Million"))
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

All countries beyond rate divided to 2 groups: Above the red line - high
excess mortality Between the line - not an irregular excess mortality
Under the blue line
:::

::: {#b.-7 .section .level4}
#### b.

Plotting three outlier countries(above 2000) in terms of
`excess_mortality`.

``` r
cov_mortality = subset(covid_df, location %in% c('Bulgaria', 'Mexico', 'South Africa'), select = c("location", "total_deaths_per_million","excess_mortality_cumulative_per_million", "date"))

ggplot(na.omit(cov_mortality), aes_string(x='date', color = 'location')) +
  geom_line(aes(y=total_deaths_per_million, linetype = 'Total Deaths')) + 
  geom_line(aes(y=excess_mortality_cumulative_per_million, linetype = "Excess Mortality")) +
  theme_bw() +
  scale_x_date(name = 'Date') +
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Total Deaths (dashed) & Excess Mortality (solid)") +
  ggtitle("Total Deaths & Excess Mortality By Date")
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

In Mexico the tendency of excess mortality is most of the time above
total deaths. In South Africa and Bulgaria we can see that at the end of
2020 tendency of excess mortality and the tendency of total deaths
turned. We can infer that the uprise of the second variant which is less
deadly and the fact that a lot of endangered populations have already
died changed the tendencies.
:::
:::
:::
:::
:::
